As a Japanese male employee in a mid-sized company in Tokyo, I strongly agree with the statement that one can be a good manager without having a precise answer to every question that a subordinate may raise about their work. While it is important for managers to have a thorough understanding of their team's work and be able to answer any questions that may arise, it is equally important for managers to understand the bigger picture and delegate tasks effectively.

A good manager should be able to prioritize tasks and allocate resources accordingly, rather than getting bogged down in the details of every individual task. By focusing on the larger goals and objectives, a manager can ensure that their team is working towards common goals and making progress towards achieving them.

Additionally, a manager should be able to trust their team members to complete their tasks and delegate tasks effectively. By giving team members the autonomy to complete their work, a manager can foster a sense of ownership and investment in their team's success. This can lead to increased productivity and job satisfaction, as well as a more cohesive and effective team.

In conclusion, while having a precise answer to every question may be desirable, it is not the most important quality for a good manager. A manager who understands the bigger picture and can delegate tasks effectively is better equipped to lead their team to success.

Instead, a good manager should possess qualities such as emotional intelligence, empathy, and effective communication skills. They should be able to listen actively, understand the concerns of their subordinates, and provide guidance and support when needed.

Moreover, managers should be willing to admit when they don't have an answer and should be open to learning and seeking advice from their team members. This not only fosters a culture of collaboration and trust but also enables the manager to make informed decisions based on a collective understanding of the situation.

In conclusion, while having all the answers may be ideal, it is not a prerequisite for being an effective and respected manager. A good manager should prioritize communication, empathy, and adaptation to the ever-changing needs of their team.
